comment.author: 44336021@N05
comment._content: "Yours Aye Malcolm Cockerell" - There was an 'Mr M Cockerell' on board the Ship Karoola (H. McDonald. Master) from Fremantle - Adelaide - Melbourne to Sydney Arriving 21 Mar 1910. If thats any help

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/44336021@N05] A possibility! I was kind of hoping he'd turn out to be a film star - he looks so dashing!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 35607158@N06
comment._content: I notice in the lower left it is printed "Mr. Malcolm Cockerell" suggesting this is one of a number of such images.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/jamica1] Interestingly there is a census record for a Malcolm Cockerell 1911 age 29, occupation : Actor, Chiddington St Fullham...
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 110497222@N02
comment._content: We have letters written in the 1940s by the Malcolm Cockerell who was the actor mentioned above in the 1911 census, and the writing does look similar to the signature on this photo, particularly the way he writes Malcolm. He married and lived in France after WW1. However, we don't have any photos to compare.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/110497222@N02] I wonder then if he's the same Malcolm Cockerell as the chap mentioned here www.kingsownmuseum.plus.com/goldenrollofhonour.htm ; he's also mentioned in a few Australian newspapers in the 1930s...He was then living in France...I gather he made some kind of income by providing relatives with details of their loved one's graves.

comment.author: 110497222@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] 
I haven't looked at the Australian newspapers but from what's in the letters I'm sure the chap in the link you give is the same Malcolm Cockerell.
